Derivatives of exponentials

Suppose \(f(x) = a^x\) for some constant \(a>0\).  Now the variable \(x\) is in the power, not the base, so our usual formula for differentiating powers of \(x\) does not apply: the functions \(x^2\) and \(2^x\) are two very different functions.  How then can we differentiate this function \(f\)?  Let us consider the definition of the derivative.  Using the laws of indices, we have that \[ \begin{align*} f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{a^{x+h} - a^x}{h}\\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{a^x a^h - a^x}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{a^x ( a^h - 1)}{h} \\ &= a^x \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{a^h - 1}{h}. \end{align*} \] Here we have been able to move the \(a^x\) outside the limit, because it does not depend on \(h\), which is the variable in which the limit is taken.  The point is that the value of this limit of difference quotients depends on the value of the limit \[ \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{a^h - 1}{h}, \] which we notice is exactly the definition of the value of the derivative of \(f\) at \(0\): \[ f'(0) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(0+h)-f(0)}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{a^{0+h} - a^0}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{a^h - 1}{h}. \] So in general, for \(f(x)=a^x\) we have that \[ f'(x) = a^x f'(0) = f(x)f'(0), \] where \(f'(0)\) is a fixed value that depends only on the value of our base \(a\).  This in particular gives a rigorous demonstration of a characteristic feature of exponential growth: that the rate of change (the derivative) depends on the value of the function itself.  Thus (unregulated) population size typically behaves exponentially, since the larger a population, the faster it grows, since there are more individuals reproducing.


The number \(e \approx 2.71828\) which met met in detail in week 4, satisfies \[ \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{e^h - 1}{h} = 1. \] In fact this is one way to define the value \(e\).  So for the natural exponential function \(y = e^x\), we have \(\dfrac{dy}{dx} = e^x\).  In other words, the derivative is equal to the function itself.

\[ \mbox{Suppose } f(x) = e^x. \mbox{ Then } f'(x) = e^x = f(x). \]


Derivative of the logarithm

The natural logarithm \(f(x) = \ln (x)\) is defined to be the inverse of the exponential function \(e^x\).  Since \(e^x\) only produces positive numbers, \(\ln(x)\) is only defined for positive numbers, and is defined such that the equation \[ e^{\ln(x)} = x \] holds for all \(x> 0\).

\[ \mbox{Suppose } f(x) = \ln(x). \mbox{ Then } f'(x) = 1/x. \]
